ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, Jeff, thanks for the feedback! Regarding novelty search as *not* being objective-driven, I (now) agree with both of you that it is misleading to classify

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Ken, Jeff, thanks for the feedback!

Regarding novelty search as *not* being objective-driven, I (now) agree
with both of you that it is misleading to classify it as an implicit
objective function, though novelty search is also a user-defined function
that can be used during optimization. The difference between explicit and
implicit fitness functions is more to be found on the level of details used
to write the objective function (of course, i agree there is a continuum
between the two), which may depend on the background knowledge available to
the designer. Novelty is quite orthogonal to this classification (and
should be removed from my table), and could be relevant whether we are
dealing with an objective-driven or an environment-driven
learning/adaptation problem.

Then, I would still defend that the difference between objective-driven and
environment-driven is an essential one, and I would not say that
environment-driven is a synonym of non-objective-driven. The fact that the
environment (rather than a pre-defined objective function) shapes the
learning/adaptation process also implies to be able to capture (explicitly
or not) the possibly dynamic fitness function(s) hidden within the
environment. With an objective-driven problem, you may be already one step
ahead as you get a formulation of the objective from the start, but you may
also be misleaded if the ultimate goal is to, say, just survive, and you
have few, possibly wrong, assumptions on how to achieve such a goal. In
this context, i guess you'd be better starting off with no assumption and
gradualy improving using feedback directly from the environment. In both
cases though, you may end up in one particular region of the search space -
which is different from what you expect from a non-objective-driven search.

Surely, it depends on the problem at hand and I guess what I say there is
influenced by my own work about self-adaptive (ie. environment-driven)
swarm of autonomous agents: in this scope, we used some pretty
straight-forward random selection mechanisms (as selection pressure is
indirectly at work at the swarm level), sometimes slightly biased by, for
example, kin-selection and alike. From this perspective, selection pressure
towards novelty could be used to maintain some kind of diversity and
pressure towards innovation within the population, which may turn out to be
an efficient way to survive whenever, say, the environment changes (we did
not try it yet, though, and i guess it would require more than a naive
implementation to take the full benefit out of it). Hence, novelty would
stand as a mean to an end, but not as the objective per se.

Of course, as you both said, the true challenge with open-ended evolution
remains to identify which are the properties and/or mechanisms to truly
achieve it. Adding a pressure towards novelty may be one part of the
solution, as would be considering a pressure towards complexity, niching,
etc. Still, this does not define the problems, as my initial classification
was about, but it rather sketches a yet-to-be-completed roadmap towards
open-ended evolution.

Nicolas

ps: for the record, note that the original distinction between implicit and
explicit fitness functions is discussed extensively in Nolfi and Floreano's
book on ER from 2000, p. 67.

--f46d04088d1158efeb04cc15477a
Content-Type: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
